news_summary: Innovative environmental solutions are advancing sustainable shrimp farming, enforcing global climate action through legal rulings, exploring waste-to-resource technologies, and providing clean drinking water by harvesting fog.
news_summary_fr: Des solutions environnementales innovantes permettent de faire progresser l'élevage durable de crevettes, d'imposer une action climatique mondiale par le biais de décisions judiciaires, d'explorer les technologies de transformation des déchets en ressources et de fournir de l'eau potable grâce à la récolte du brouillard.
news_summary_es: Las soluciones medioambientales innovadoras promueven la cría sostenible de camarones, imponen la acción climática mundial mediante sentencias judiciales, exploran tecnologías de conversión de residuos en recursos y proporcionan agua potable mediante la recogida de niebla.

articles.title: Is there a better way to farm shrimp? A new project says yes
articles.summary: The world’s appetite for shrimp has surged — and environmental destruction has followed in its wake. A new program from Conservation International has a solution.
articles.content:
The shrimp on your plate has a story.

Over the past three decades, the world’s appetite for shrimp has surged — almost tenfold. Wild shrimp stocks alone can’t keep up with this demand, so farming shrimp has filled the gap.

But this rapid growth has come at a heavy cost. Mangrove forests — which shelter life along many of the world’s tropical coasts and absorb gobs of climate-warming carbon — have been cleared to make way for shrimp farms.

The carbon footprint of this devastation is enormous: A 2017 study found that the climate impact of a steak and shrimp dinner — were it to come from shrimp farms and pasture formerly occupied by mangroves — is the same as driving a small car across the continental United States.

Now, in the coastal village of Lalombi in Central Sulawesi, Indonesia, a new chapter to the story is unfolding — one that includes more shrimp and more mangroves.

This June brought the first harvest of shrimp raised using a new “Climate Smart Shrimp” approach pioneered by Conservation International.

“The equation is simple,” said Dane Klinger, who leads the organization’s Climate Smart Shrimp program. “We’re helping farmers grow more shrimp on less land, so that they can return the rest of their farms back to mangroves. It’s a shift that we think could disrupt the entire industry to make it not just more sustainable, but more productive and profitable, too.”

For years, shrimp farms followed a familiar pattern: Clear the mangroves, dig the ponds and harvest what you can.

But as global demand for shrimp has grown, many farmers have pushed their farms to the limit to produce more in the same space. This comes with risks: Crowded ponds can increase disease outbreaks, while runoff pollutes waterways and damages delicate coastal ecosystems. A “boom-and-bust” cycle begins, forcing farmers to abandon or rotate ponds frequently, driving expansion into the few remaining mangroves left.

© Viga Ananda Wicaksono

Young mangroves emerge in restored mangrove habitat.

In Lalombi, that pattern is shifting.

Backed by Conservation International’s local affiliate, Konservasi Indonesia, the Indonesia-based start-up JALA purchased a shrimp farm in Lalombi that had previously been abandoned, low-productivity shrimp ponds. Here, they’ve adopted a more efficient farming model that responsibly boosts production while shrinking the climate footprint of the ponds.

“We’ve made a lot of changes,” said Aryo Wiryawan, founder of JALA. “We’re preparing our ponds more carefully, using better tools to monitor shrimp health, and managing waste more effectively. All of this has helped improve survival rates and allowed us to raise more shrimp in the same space.”

The farmers are paying close attention to everything from how much feed the shrimp receive to the temperature, oxygen levels and salinity of the water — all key to creating the right conditions for healthy growth. Some ponds use aerators to boost oxygen levels or automated feeders to optimize nutrition. Pond liners, often made of plastic or concrete, help provide farmers more control over the environment.

These approaches appear to be paying off. The first harvest at the Lalombi farm brought in 52 tons per hectare — well above average.

“With better survival rates and healthier shrimp, the income per cycle has increased,” Wiryawan said. “This early trajectory suggests that the Climate Smart Shrimp approach — combining smart tech, regenerative practices and better farm management — can deliver both ecological and economic benefits.”

And in spaces no longer needed for ponds, mangroves are being restored, one sapling at a time. Early signs suggest it’s working.

Mariska Astrid, a researcher at Indonesia’s National Research and Innovation Agency, helped survey the water quality at the Lalombi farm and the surrounding mangrove areas to assess their natural filtration role.

© Konservasi Indonesia

Scientists from Indonesia's National Research and Innovation Agency collect water samples during the harvest to assess water quality in the shrimp ponds and restored mangrove habitat.

“Previously, wastewater from shrimp ponds was foamy due to high chemical and phosphorus content,” Astrid said. “After passing through the wastewater treatment system and natural mangrove filtration, the foam disappeared, and the water became clear — safe for discharge into the sea.”

It’s a small but promising sign for Indonesia — one of the most biodiverse countries on Earth, but one with one of the world’s highest deforestation rates. Significant portions of the mangroves on Sulawesi have been damaged or destroyed since the 1980s.

Over time, these coastlines once cleared for shrimp could become a renewed haven for native wildlife — from darting schools of fish to mudskippers, fiddler crabs, herons and kingfishers.

“Every shrimp on your plate has a story,” Wiryawan said. “It’s connected to a community, an ecosystem and a farmer trying to make the right choices. What you eat matters — it can drive real change.”

Conservation International has now turned its attention to scaling climate smart shrimp by attracting more investment in the model. A recent grant from Convergence will enable Conservation International and partners to design and raise a loan fund to finance adoption of climate smart shrimp practices across Indonesia.

This project was made possible through the generous support of the Caterpillar Foundation. Since its founding in 1952, Caterpillar Foundation has helped improve the lives of people around the world by investing in the skills people need to join the modern workforce, and the natural and vital infrastructure they rely upon.

Will McCarry is the content director at Conservation International. Want to read more stories like this? Sign up for email updates. Also, please consider supporting our critical work.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights an innovative project aimed at addressing the environmental damage caused by shrimp farming, offering a sustainable solution. This represents environmental progress and conservation efforts, which are positive and hopeful developments.
articles.personality_title: A new way to farm shrimp protects nature and the climate
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Shrimp has become a favorite food worldwide, and demand has grown nearly ten times in the past 30 years. To meet this hunger, shrimp farming has expanded quickly, but it has also caused serious harm by cutting down mangrove forests. These forests are important because they provide homes for many animals and help fight climate change by storing carbon.

**What happened**
Conservation International started a new project that offers a smarter, kinder way to farm shrimp. Instead of destroying mangroves, this method focuses on protecting these forests while raising shrimp. By combining nature-friendly farming techniques with careful planning, the project helps keep the environment safe and the shrimp supply steady.

**Impact**
This approach means fewer mangroves are lost, which keeps valuable carbon stored and wildlife safe. It also supports local communities who depend on the forest and shrimp farming for their livelihoods. Protecting mangroves while farming shrimp shows it’s possible to balance food production with environmental care.

**What's next step**
The project aims to expand this sustainable shrimp farming method to more coastal areas around the world. By sharing knowledge and working with local farmers, they hope to make this model the new standard for shrimp production, reducing harm everywhere shrimp is farmed.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A new shrimp farming method proves we can enjoy our favorite seafood while saving vital forests and fighting climate change.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle façon d’élever des crevettes protège la nature et le climat
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les crevettes sont devenues un aliment très apprécié dans le monde, et la demande a presque décuplé en 30 ans. Pour répondre à cet appétit, l’élevage de crevettes s’est rapidement développé, mais cela a aussi causé de graves dégâts en détruisant les mangroves. Ces forêts sont importantes car elles abritent de nombreux animaux et aident à lutter contre le changement climatique en stockant du carbone.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Conservation International a lancé un nouveau projet qui propose une manière plus intelligente et respectueuse d’élever des crevettes. Au lieu de détruire les mangroves, cette méthode protège ces forêts tout en élevant les crevettes. Grâce à des techniques d’élevage respectueuses de la nature et une planification soignée, le projet aide à préserver l’environnement tout en assurant une production stable.

**Impact**
Cette approche limite la perte des mangroves, ce qui permet de garder le carbone stocké et de protéger la faune. Elle soutient aussi les communautés locales qui dépendent des forêts et de l’élevage des crevettes pour vivre. Protéger les mangroves tout en élevant des crevettes montre qu’il est possible de concilier alimentation et soin de la nature.

**Prochaine étape**
Le projet souhaite étendre cette méthode durable à d’autres zones côtières dans le monde. En partageant les connaissances et en travaillant avec les agriculteurs locaux, ils espèrent faire de ce modèle la nouvelle norme pour la production de crevettes, réduisant ainsi les dégâts partout où elles sont élevées.

**Une phrase clé**
Une nouvelle méthode d’élevage de crevettes montre qu’il est possible de profiter de nos fruits de mer préférés tout en sauvant des forêts vitales et en luttant contre le changement climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: Una nueva forma de cultivar camarones protege la naturaleza y el clima
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los camarones se han convertido en un alimento favorito en todo el mundo, y la demanda ha crecido casi diez veces en los últimos 30 años. Para satisfacer esta demanda, la crianza de camarones se ha expandido rápidamente, pero también ha causado graves daños al talar los bosques de manglares. Estos bosques son importantes porque albergan muchos animales y ayudan a combatir el cambio climático almacenando carbono.

**Qué pasó**
Conservation International comenzó un nuevo proyecto que ofrece una forma más inteligente y amable de criar camarones. En lugar de destruir los manglares, este método protege estos bosques mientras cría camarones. Combinando técnicas de crianza respetuosas con la naturaleza y una planificación cuidadosa, el proyecto ayuda a mantener el medio ambiente seguro y el suministro de camarones estable.

**Impacto**
Este enfoque significa que se pierden menos manglares, lo que mantiene el carbono almacenado y protege la vida silvestre. También apoya a las comunidades locales que dependen del bosque y la cría de camarones para vivir. Proteger los manglares mientras se crían camarones demuestra que es posible equilibrar la producción de alimentos con el cuidado del medio ambiente.

**Próximo paso**
El proyecto busca expandir este método sostenible de crianza de camarones a más áreas costeras en todo el mundo. Compartiendo conocimientos y trabajando con agricultores locales, esperan hacer de este modelo el nuevo estándar para la producción de camarones, reduciendo el daño donde sea que se críen.

**Conclusión en una oración**
Un nuevo método de crianza de camarones demuestra que podemos disfrutar de nuestros mariscos favoritos mientras salvamos bosques vitales y luchamos contra el cambio climático.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed warm painting of a vibrant coastal scene at dawn, showing lush young mangrove saplings growing along the shoreline beside a series of neatly arranged, gently rippling shrimp ponds with aerators and feeding devices, flocks of colorful kingfishers and herons flying above, and schools of fish visible beneath the clear water, all rendered in soft natural greens, blues, and earth tones to symbolize sustainable shrimp farming and mangrove restoration.

articles.title: World Court Rules Tackling Climate Crisis is an International Legal Obligation
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Ralph Regenvanu, Vanuatu's minister for climate change, speaks surrounded by demonstrators at the International Court of Justice ahead of an advisory opinion on what legal obligations nations have to address climate change in The Hague, Netherlands, July 23, 2025.
                    © 2025 Peter Dejong/AP Photo
          
    


  
The International Court of Justice (ICJ) issued a unanimous opinion on July 23, 2025, that climate change is "an existential problem of planetary proportions that imperils all forms of life and the very health of our planet."The long-awaited Advisory Opinion on the Obligations of States in respect of Climate Change is a milestone. The decision comes after five years of tireless campaigning by youth advocates—led by the Pacific Islands Students Fighting Climate Change and World’s Youth for Climate Justice—and diplomatic efforts led by Vanuatu.  Back in 2022, Human Rights Watch joined 220 other civil society organizations calling on states to support the advisory opinion request before the United Nations General Assembly, which passed in 2023.The court heard legal arguments from nearly 100 countries and international organizations before answering the two questions posed by the General Assembly: what are the obligations of states under international law with respect to climate change, and what are the legal consequences when such duties are breached and cause harm to people and states?The court said that climate change’s impacts on human rights require “mitigation and adaptation measures, with due account given to the protection of human rights, the adoption of standards and legislation, and the regulation of the activities of private actors.”The court also ruled that failure of a state to take appropriate action to protect the climate system from emissions—like fossil fuel production, consumption, exploration or the provision subsidies—may violate international law. Human Rights Watch has documented how fossil fuel production harms the rights of communities adjacent to fossil fuel infrastructure.The court also acknowledged that “conditions resulting from climate change which are likely to endanger the lives of individuals may lead them to seek safety in another country or prevent them from returning to their own,” urging countries to avoid sending individuals back to their country of origin in such circumstances.And the court concluded that countries’ failure to protect the climate system triggers legal consequences, including revoking all measures contributing to climate harm.States should now revise their national commitments on greenhouse gas emissions to collectively stay under the limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius of additional warming established by the Paris Agreement. Human Rights Watch will continue to push countries to commit to ambitious climate plans and a fossil fuel phaseout.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Ralph Regenvanu, Vanuatu's minister for climate change, speaks surrounded by demonstrators at the International Court of Justice ahead of an advisory opinion on what legal obligations nations have to address climate change in The Hague, Netherlands, July 23, 2025. © 2025 Peter Dejong/AP Photo

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) issued a unanimous opinion on July 23, 2025, that climate change is "an existential problem of planetary proportions that imperils all forms of life and the very health of our planet."

The long-awaited Advisory Opinion on the Obligations of States in respect of Climate Change is a milestone. The decision comes after five years of tireless campaigning by youth advocates—led by the Pacific Islands Students Fighting Climate Change and World’s Youth for Climate Justice—and diplomatic efforts led by Vanuatu. Back in 2022, Human Rights Watch joined 220 other civil society organizations calling on states to support the advisory opinion request before the United Nations General Assembly, which passed in 2023.

The court heard legal arguments from nearly 100 countries and international organizations before answering the two questions posed by the General Assembly: what are the obligations of states under international law with respect to climate change, and what are the legal consequences when such duties are breached and cause harm to people and states?

The court said that climate change’s impacts on human rights require “mitigation and adaptation measures, with due account given to the protection of human rights, the adoption of standards and legislation, and the regulation of the activities of private actors.”

The court also ruled that failure of a state to take appropriate action to protect the climate system from emissions—like fossil fuel production, consumption, exploration or the provision subsidies—may violate international law. Human Rights Watch has documented how fossil fuel production harms the rights of communities adjacent to fossil fuel infrastructure.

The court also acknowledged that “conditions resulting from climate change which are likely to endanger the lives of individuals may lead them to seek safety in another country or prevent them from returning to their own,” urging countries to avoid sending individuals back to their country of origin in such circumstances.

And the court concluded that countries’ failure to protect the climate system triggers legal consequences, including revoking all measures contributing to climate harm.

States should now revise their national commitments on greenhouse gas emissions to collectively stay under the limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius of additional warming established by the Paris Agreement. Human Rights Watch will continue to push countries to commit to ambitious climate plans and a fossil fuel phaseout.
articles.reasoning: The International Court of Justice's ruling establishes a clear legal obligation for states to tackle climate change, recognizing it as an existential threat and linking it to human rights protections. This milestone decision reflects successful global cooperation, youth advocacy, and sets a strong foundation for future climate action and accountability, which is hopeful and inspiring for the planet's future.
articles.personality_title: World court declares fighting climate change a legal duty for all nations
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The International Court of Justice (ICJ), the top global legal body, was asked to clarify whether countries have legal responsibilities to address climate change. This comes after years of pressure from youth activists, island nations, and many civil society groups highlighting the urgent threat climate change poses to people and the planet.

**What happened**
On July 23, 2025, the ICJ gave a unanimous opinion declaring that climate change is a serious danger to all life and the planet’s health. They ruled that countries must take action to reduce harmful emissions, create laws protecting human rights affected by climate change, and regulate private companies contributing to the problem. Ignoring these duties, like continuing fossil fuel production or subsidies, can violate international law and cause legal consequences.

**Impact**
This decision is historic because it legally links climate action to human rights protection and holds nations accountable. It supports those already affected by climate change, including people forced to move for safety. It also pushes governments to strengthen their emission targets and work together to keep global warming below 1.5 degrees Celsius, as agreed in the Paris Agreement.

**What's next step**
Countries will need to review and update their climate plans to meet these legal obligations. Groups like Human Rights Watch will continue advocating for stronger measures and a global phaseout of fossil fuels to protect communities and the planet’s future.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The world’s highest court has made it clear: tackling climate change is not just a choice, but a legal responsibility for every country.
articles.personality_title_fr: La cour mondiale déclare que lutter contre le changement climatique est un devoir légal pour tous les pays
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La Cour internationale de justice (CIJ), la plus haute instance juridique mondiale, a été sollicitée pour clarifier si les pays ont des responsabilités légales face au changement climatique. Cela fait suite à des années de pression des jeunes militants, des nations insulaires et de nombreux groupes de la société civile soulignant la menace urgente que représente le changement climatique pour les populations et la planète.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Le 23 juillet 2025, la CIJ a rendu un avis unanime déclarant que le changement climatique est un danger sérieux pour toute vie et la santé de la planète. Elle a jugé que les pays doivent agir pour réduire les émissions nocives, créer des lois protégeant les droits humains affectés par le changement climatique, et réguler les entreprises privées qui contribuent au problème. Ignorer ces devoirs, comme poursuivre la production de combustibles fossiles ou les subventions, peut violer le droit international et entraîner des conséquences juridiques.

**Impact**
Cette décision est historique car elle lie légalement l'action climatique à la protection des droits humains et tient les nations responsables. Elle soutient ceux déjà affectés par le changement climatique, y compris les personnes forcées de se déplacer pour leur sécurité. Elle pousse aussi les gouvernements à renforcer leurs objectifs d'émissions et à coopérer pour maintenir le réchauffement mondial en dessous de 1,5 degrés Celsius, comme prévu par l'Accord de Paris.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les pays devront revoir et mettre à jour leurs plans climatiques pour respecter ces obligations légales. Des groupes comme Human Rights Watch continueront à défendre des mesures plus fortes et une suppression progressive mondiale des combustibles fossiles pour protéger les communautés et l'avenir de la planète.

**Une phrase clé à retenir**
La plus haute cour mondiale a clairement dit : lutter contre le changement climatique n’est pas un choix, mais une responsabilité légale pour chaque pays.
articles.personality_title_es: El tribunal mundial declara que combatir el cambio climático es un deber legal para todos los países
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La Corte Internacional de Justicia (CIJ), el máximo órgano legal global, fue consultada para aclarar si los países tienen responsabilidades legales para enfrentar el cambio climático. Esto llega tras años de presión de jóvenes activistas, naciones insulares y muchos grupos de la sociedad civil que destacan la amenaza urgente que representa el cambio climático para las personas y el planeta.

**Qué pasó**
El 23 de julio de 2025, la CIJ emitió una opinión unánime declarando que el cambio climático es un peligro serio para toda la vida y la salud del planeta. Dictaminó que los países deben actuar para reducir las emisiones dañinas, crear leyes que protejan los derechos humanos afectados por el cambio climático y regular a las empresas privadas que contribuyen al problema. Ignorar estos deberes, como continuar la producción o subsidios de combustibles fósiles, puede violar la ley internacional y causar consecuencias legales.

**Impacto**
Esta decisión es histórica porque vincula legalmente la acción climática con la protección de los derechos humanos y responsabiliza a las naciones. Apoya a quienes ya están afectados por el cambio climático, incluyendo a las personas que deben desplazarse por seguridad. También impulsa a los gobiernos a fortalecer sus objetivos de emisiones y a trabajar juntos para mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 1,5 grados Celsius, como se acordó en el Acuerdo de París.

**Próximo paso**
Los países deberán revisar y actualizar sus planes climáticos para cumplir con estas obligaciones legales. Organizaciones como Human Rights Watch seguirán abogando por medidas más fuertes y la eliminación progresiva global de los combustibles fósiles para proteger a las comunidades y el futuro del planeta.

**Una frase para recordar**
La corte más alta del mundo ha dejado claro: combatir el cambio climático no es una opción, sino una responsabilidad legal para cada país.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a large globe gently cradled by diverse, translucent hands symbolizing international unity, with vibrant young seedlings emerging from the globe’s surface representing youth climate advocates, all set against a calm, soft sky in natural earth tones conveying hope and collective responsibility to protect the planet.

articles.title: Why a tech start-up wants to pump your faeces deep underground
articles.summary: Start-up Vaulted Deep, which has funding from Microsoft, says storing human waste deep underground can keep carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere and pollutants like forever chemicals out of surface ecosystems
articles.content:
Start-up Vaulted Deep, which has funding from Microsoft, says storing human waste deep underground can keep carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere and pollutants like forever chemicals out of surface ecosystems

Processing tanks at a site in Kansas where waste is pumped into an underground salt cavern Vaulted Deep

A start-up called Vaulted Deep has signed a deal with Microsoft to pump millions of tonnes of treated human excrement, manure and other organic waste deep underground as a way to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. This approach could also avoid above ground contamination from PFAS “forever chemicals” and other chemical pollutants leaching out of the waste.

“We solve these two problems at once,” says Omar Abou-Sayed at Vaulted Deep. “We solve waste issues that impact local water, local air, local land, but we also do it in a way that addresses climate.”

Over the past few years, the Texas-based company has injected nearly 70,000 tonnes of carbon-rich waste deep underground, amounting to over 18,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide removed. The company’s approach is enabled by technology developed for the oil and gas industry that can inject a slurry of liquids, solids and gases underground all at once. This type of waste is normally put in landfills or spread on fields.

Injecting the waste far underground prevents it from decomposing and releasing the carbon it contains back into the atmosphere for thousands – and potentially millions – of years, says Abou-Sayed. The company then sells each tonne of CO2 removed from circulation to companies or governments to count against their own emissions.

The agreement with Microsoft to remove 4.9 million tonnes of CO2 over the next 12 years comes as the carbon dioxide removal industry has faced challenges attracting customers. Microsoft has purchased more carbon removal credits than any other corporation in its bid to be carbon negative by 2030.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

Abou-Sayed says the deal will allow Vaulted Deep to develop new injection sites, beyond its two current locations. One, in Los Angeles, injects “biosolids” left over from treated wastewater about 1600 metres below the surface. The second site is in Hutchinson, Kansas, where human waste, manure and other organic material like paper sludge are injected into a salt cavern a few hundred metres belowground.

By one estimate, the world generates enough organic waste for this approach to remove as much as 5 billion tonnes of CO2 from the atmosphere each year, enough to meet much of the CO2 removals needed to get to net zero emissions.

Vaulted Deep’s goal now is to get access to as much of that waste as possible, especially the wet-solid slurries that can’t be used in other ways. “One of the things we’ve become expert at is identifying the locations of these sludgy wastes,” says Abou-Sayed. They sometimes offer to dispose of it for free, or even pay the waste generator to take it off their hands.

The system injects waste deep underground Vaulted Deep

Storing the waste underground rather than spreading it on fields or in landfills can also reduce levels of pollution at the surface, because nitrogen and PFAS are concentrated in the waste, says Abou-Sayed. Some municipalities have run into trouble finding conventional ways to dispose of such refuse, in part due to tightening restrictions on PFAS contamination.

“It’s very novel,” says Diana Oviedo Vargas at the Stroud Water Research Center in Pennsylvania. “We need as many approaches as we can to try and deal with the issue of contaminants. Not just PFAS.” However, she points out injecting the waste deep underground doesn’t actually destroy the contaminants. “It’s kind of out of sight out of mind,” she says.

In order to ensure the injections are safe, Abou-Sayed says every site goes through a detailed permitting process managed by the US Environmental Protection Agency. They are required to prove the slurry won’t leak out of the storage area into groundwater or come back out of the well, and to minimise the risk of triggering seismic activity with the injection process.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses an innovative environmental solution by a tech start-up to store human waste underground, which helps reduce carbon dioxide emissions and prevents pollutants from contaminating ecosystems. This represents environmental progress and the use of technology to solve real-world problems.
articles.personality_title: A start-up’s clever plan to store waste underground helps fight pollution
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
A new tech start-up called Vaulted Deep has teamed up with Microsoft to find a smarter way to handle human waste. By storing treated waste deep underground, they aim to reduce harmful gases and stop pollutants from reaching our land and water.

**What happened**
Vaulted Deep is pumping treated human waste, manure, and organic materials into underground salt caverns. These natural formations are far below the surface, safely trapping carbon dioxide—a major cause of climate change—and stopping harmful chemicals, sometimes called ‘forever chemicals,’ from leaking into ecosystems.

**Impact**
This approach keeps carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere, helping slow global warming. It also protects soil and water from dangerous pollutants, making the environment cleaner and safer. The involvement of a tech giant like Microsoft shows this solution has strong support and potential to grow.

**What’s next step**
The start-up plans to expand this underground storage method, refining the process to handle more waste efficiently and safely. Continued collaboration with companies and governments could help make this a widely used way to tackle pollution and climate change.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Vaulted Deep’s underground waste storage offers a promising, high-tech way to reduce pollution and protect our planet’s future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le plan ingénieux d'une start-up pour stocker les déchets sous terre aide à lutter contre la pollution
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Une nouvelle start-up technologique appelée Vaulted Deep s'est associée à Microsoft pour trouver un moyen plus intelligent de gérer les déchets humains. En stockant les déchets traités profondément sous terre, ils visent à réduire les gaz nocifs et à empêcher les polluants d'atteindre nos sols et nos eaux.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Vaulted Deep pompe des déchets humains traités, du fumier et des matières organiques dans des cavernes de sel souterraines. Ces formations naturelles sont très profondes, emprisonnant en toute sécurité le dioxyde de carbone — un grand contributeur au changement climatique — et empêchant les produits chimiques dangereux, parfois appelés « produits chimiques éternels », de se répandre dans les écosystèmes.

**Impact**
Cette méthode empêche le dioxyde de carbone d'entrer dans l'atmosphère, aidant à ralentir le réchauffement climatique. Elle protège également le sol et l'eau des polluants dangereux, rendant l'environnement plus propre et plus sûr. L'implication d'un géant technologique comme Microsoft montre que cette solution a un fort soutien et un potentiel de développement.

**Prochaine étape**
La start-up prévoit d'étendre cette méthode de stockage souterrain, d'améliorer le processus pour gérer plus de déchets de manière efficace et sûre. Une collaboration continue avec des entreprises et des gouvernements pourrait aider à faire de cette solution une pratique courante pour lutter contre la pollution et le changement climatique.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Le stockage des déchets sous terre par Vaulted Deep offre une solution technologique prometteuse pour réduire la pollution et protéger l'avenir de notre planète.
articles.personality_title_es: El plan ingenioso de una start-up para almacenar desechos bajo tierra ayuda a combatir la contaminación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Una nueva start-up tecnológica llamada Vaulted Deep se ha unido a Microsoft para encontrar una forma más inteligente de manejar los desechos humanos. Al almacenar los desechos tratados en lo profundo de la tierra, buscan reducir los gases nocivos y evitar que los contaminantes lleguen a nuestro suelo y agua.

**Qué pasó**
Vaulted Deep bombea desechos humanos tratados, estiércol y materiales orgánicos en cavernas de sal subterráneas. Estas formaciones naturales están muy profundas, atrapando de manera segura el dióxido de carbono — una gran causa del cambio climático — y evitando que productos químicos dañinos, a veces llamados 'químicos eternos', se filtren en los ecosistemas.

**Impacto**
Este método mantiene el dióxido de carbono fuera de la atmósfera, ayudando a frenar el calentamiento global. También protege el suelo y el agua de contaminantes peligrosos, haciendo el ambiente más limpio y seguro. La participación de un gigante tecnológico como Microsoft muestra que esta solución tiene un fuerte apoyo y potencial para crecer.

**Próximo paso**
La start-up planea expandir este método de almacenamiento subterráneo, mejorando el proceso para manejar más desechos de manera eficiente y segura. La colaboración continua con empresas y gobiernos podría ayudar a que esta sea una forma común de enfrentar la contaminación y el cambio climático.

**Una frase para recordar**
El almacenamiento subterráneo de desechos de Vaulted Deep ofrece una forma tecnológica prometedora para reducir la contaminación y proteger el futuro de nuestro planeta.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting showing a large underground salt cavern beneath gently rolling fields, with stylized streams of organic waste slurry flowing safely into the cavern through pipes, while above ground a lush, clean landscape thrives symbolizing protected air, water, and soil under a soft, natural color palette.

articles.title: The Bright Side: Morocco turns fog into drinking water
articles.summary: For the past six years, Morocco has endured a severe drought that has drastically affected agriculture and water availability. Olive groves and vineyards have withered, and wells in remote mountain villages are drying up. Accessing groundwater by drilling deeper is expensive and often out of reach for many communities. In response, scientists in southern Morocco have implemented a pioneering solution: large fog-harvesting nets installed at altitudes above 1,200 metres. These nets capture moisture from coastal fogs, collecting water droplets that flow into storage tanks.
articles.content:
Morocco is home to the world’s largest fog harvesting installations and is planning to expand this technology as part of its strategy to combat climate change and water scarcity.

One of your browser extensions seems to be blocking the video player from loading. To watch this content, you may need to disable it on this site.

To display this content from YouTube, you must enable advertisement tracking and audience measurement.

Reading time 1 min

For the past six years, Morocco has endured a severe drought that has drastically affected agriculture and water availability. Olive groves and vineyards have withered, and wells in remote mountain villages are drying up. Accessing groundwater by drilling deeper is expensive and often out of reach for many communities. In response, scientists in southern Morocco have implemented a pioneering solution: large fog-harvesting nets installed at altitudes above 1,200 metres. These nets capture moisture from coastal fogs, collecting water droplets that flow into storage tanks.

This sustainable and ecological system produces approximately 37,000 litres of water daily, providing reliable access to running water for nearly 1,000 people in surrounding villages.

Morocco, home to the world's largest fog harvesting installations, is planning to expand this technology as part of its strategy to combat climate change and water scarcity.

Our France 2 colleagues report, with FRANCE 24's Jennifer Ben Brahim.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights an innovative environmental solution to severe drought conditions in Morocco, where fog-harvesting technology provides much-needed drinking water to affected communities. This represents environmental progress and a technological breakthrough that directly benefits people facing water scarcity.
articles.personality_title: Morocco turns fog into drinking water with innovative nets
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Morocco has faced a tough drought for six years, causing crops like olives and grapes to suffer and drying up wells in mountain villages. Getting water from deep underground is costly and hard for many communities.

**What happened**
Scientists in southern Morocco set up large nets high in the mountains to catch fog moisture. These fog-harvesting nets collect tiny water droplets from the fog, which then flow into tanks for drinking water.

**Impact**
This method provides clean drinking water to areas where other sources are failing. Morocco now has the world’s biggest fog-harvesting system, helping people and plants survive tough dry spells.

**What's next step**
Morocco plans to expand this fog-catching technology to more regions. This will help fight water shortages and climate change effects in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By turning fog into water, Morocco is creating a smart, natural solution to drought that improves life for many communities.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Maroc transforme le brouillard en eau potable grâce à des filets innovants
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le Maroc connaît une sécheresse sévère depuis six ans, ce qui a gravement affecté les cultures comme les olives et la vigne, et asséché les puits des villages de montagne. Trouver de l'eau en profondeur coûte cher et reste difficile pour beaucoup.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des scientifiques du sud du Maroc ont installé de grands filets en altitude pour capter l’humidité du brouillard. Ces filets recueillent de petites gouttes d’eau qui s’écoulent ensuite dans des réservoirs pour être utilisées comme eau potable.

**Impact**
Cette méthode fournit de l’eau potable propre dans des zones où les autres sources disparaissent. Le Maroc possède aujourd’hui le plus grand système de collecte de brouillard au monde, aidant les personnes et les cultures à survivre aux sécheresses.

**Prochaine étape**
Le Maroc prévoit d’étendre cette technologie de capture du brouillard à d’autres régions, pour mieux lutter contre les pénuries d’eau et les effets du changement climatique.

**Message clé en une phrase**
En transformant le brouillard en eau, le Maroc crée une solution naturelle et intelligente à la sécheresse qui améliore la vie de nombreuses communautés.
articles.personality_title_es: Marruecos convierte la niebla en agua potable con redes innovadoras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Marruecos ha sufrido una sequía dura durante seis años, afectando cultivos como aceitunas y viñas, y secando pozos en aldeas de montaña. Conseguir agua subterránea profunda es caro y difícil para muchas comunidades.

**Qué pasó**
Científicos en el sur de Marruecos instalaron grandes redes en las montañas para capturar la humedad de la niebla. Estas redes recogen pequeñas gotas de agua que fluyen hacia tanques para ser usadas como agua potable.

**Impacto**
Este método proporciona agua potable limpia en zonas donde otras fuentes fallan. Marruecos ahora tiene el sistema de recolección de niebla más grande del mundo, ayudando a personas y cultivos a sobrevivir las sequías.

**Próximo paso**
Marruecos planea expandir esta tecnología para captar niebla en más regiones, ayudando a combatir la escasez de agua y los efectos del cambio climático.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Al convertir la niebla en agua, Marruecos crea una solución natural e inteligente para la sequía que mejora la vida de muchas comunidades.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of large, delicate mesh nets stretched high on mountain slopes above misty clouds, gently collecting shimmering droplets that flow down into rustic stone tanks, surrounded by dry olive groves and vineyards under a soft, muted sky, symbolizing hope and sustainable water harvesting in a drought-stricken Moroccan landscape.
